alert.note: Alert for Carbon (Wyoming) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Cheyenne (Southeastern Wyoming and Western Nebraska)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 21 at 10:49AM MDT until further notice by NWS Cheyenne
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Wyoming... Little Snake River near Little Snake River near Dixon affecting Carbon County. .Snowmelt above 9000ft will continue to create daily fluctuations on the Little Snake River this week. Rainfall this week may add to the rises. For the Little Snake River...including Little Snake River near Dixon...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Little Snake River near Little Snake River near Dixon. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 9.5 feet, Flood stage. Standing water occurs over low lying areas along the left and right river banks. Minor lowland flooding occurs near the town of Baggs. Minor lowland agricultural flooding continues to become more widespread from Dixon to Baggs. Flood wave travel time to Baggs is approximately 2 to 3 hours. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - There is no current observed data. - Forecast...The river will oscillate around flood stage at 10.0 feet through the week. - Flood stage is 9.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 10.1 feet on 02/11/1962. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (11 am MDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Mon Tue Wed Little Snake River Little Snake River near Dixo 9.5 MSG unknown 9.6 9.8 9.8 &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. Most flood related deaths occur in automobiles. Do not attempt to cross water covered bridges, dips, or low water crossings. Never try to cross a flowing stream, even a small one, on foot. To escape rising water find another route over higher ground. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued Monday afternoon at 1200 PM MDT.
